question: Question_01_(j)
statement:
\emph{\textbf{Short-Answer Questions.} Put your answer in the box
provided but show your work also. Each question is worth 3 marks, but
not all questions are of equal difficulty. Full marks will be given for
correct answers placed in the box, but at most 1 mark will be given for

simplify your answers in this question.}

Find \emph{f$^{\prime}$(x)}, where

\begin{align*}f(x)=x^{(x^2)}\end{align*}
sols:
In this case we need to use logarithmic differentiation, indeed it is
impossible to use the power rule since there is an $x^2$ as exponent. We
cannot differentiate it in the same way we do for exponential functions
since we take the power of \emph{x} and not \emph{e} or another
constant. Hence we need to use logarithmic differentiation. First set

\begin{align*}y=x^{(x^2)},\end{align*} then taking the logarithm on both sides we find

\begin{align*}\ln y = \ln (x^{(x^2)}) = x^2 \ln(x).\end{align*} Now keeping in mind that
\emph{y} is a function of \emph{x}, we can take the derivatives on both
sides and get

\begin{align*}\frac{d}{dx} \ln y = \frac{d}{dx} (x^2 \ln(x)) .\end{align*} The left-hand side
is simply

\begin{align*}\frac{d}{dx} \ln y = \frac{1}{y} \cdot \frac{d}{dx} y = \frac{1}{y} y',\end{align*}
while the right-hand side gives, using the product rule,

\begin{align*}\frac{d}{dx}(x^2 \ln(x)) = 2x \ln(x) + x^2 \frac{1}{x} =  2x \ln(x) + x.\end{align*}
Putting everything back together, we get

\begin{align*}\frac{1}{y} y' = 2x \ln(x) + x,\end{align*} and thus

\begin{align*}\displaystyle y' = y (2x \ln(x) + x).\end{align*} Replacing \emph{y} by
$x^{(x^2)},$ we finally get

\begin{align*}y' = x^{(x^2)} ( 2x \ln(x) + x).\end{align*}
hints: Can we use the power rule here? Why, or rather, \textbf{why not}?
